messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> Perhaps more important is preventing me from writing Tea-Awe-Tea for
> "tot" while Tea-Ox-Tea for "taught" which reading the QM with no
> outside material would let me do.

Well, there you are. Despite apparent concessions, QS was designed
around the RP accent (as TO was designed around an earlier version
of the London accent).

> > But if QS letters mean the same *sounds* everywhere, then instead of
> > everyone everywhere (near enough) writing At-Key-See-Et-No-Tea for
> > "accent", we must put up with It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea from New Zealand and
> > Eight-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea (or even Eight-Utter-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea)
> > from the Inland Northern U.S. I think that's intolerable.
>
> But surely this is unavoidable isn't it? I suppose it can be
> moderated some but surely there is no conceivable way to assign
> phonemes or any other abstract entity to QS letters such that all
> speakers everywhere spell all words the same.

*Some* problems are unavoidable: specifically the problems around
merged letters. We can't avoid the fact that people who don't make
certain distinctions that QS does will occasionally use a letter that
many of their readers won't expect. So if we see someone writing "Feft
is a big problem these days", we figure out that he has merged f and th,
and live with it. Likewise with "ahddity" for "oddity", and "Ah" for
"I", and "chimist" for "chemist", and "furry" for "ferry", and "pahth"
for "path", and "Cuber" for "Cuba". (I'm using Latin orthography rather
than making you decode QS by letters, but I hope you get the idear.)

But we don't have to put up with "iksent" or "ayksunt" for "accent"
(instead of "aksent"), if we accept the principle that Et is used for
whatever sound functions in the writer's dialect the way short-e functions
in "mainstream" dialects.

> What possible description of #29 would allow a west coast US accent to
> use it for both "eight" and "pair" as is done in Received Pronunciation
> English and not use #29 in words RP does not?

Everything around "r" in QS is more or less a kludge: RP speakers have
[eI] in "eight" and [e@] in "pair", but are supposed to write Eight-Roe
for the latter, although that is not what they say at all: it's
much closer to what *I* say, and my accent is not even vaguely RP.

> That reading text with varied spelling is a bit slower is not the
> end of the world. Elizabethan England functioned adequately I think.

In a totally different situation: many fewer people, a much lower
literacy rate overall, less emphasis on reading and writing in daily
life generally, and relentlessly ignoring all dialects except London's
(and maybe 40-50 miles around it). Most Elizabethan spelling variation
is random, not used to reflect people's dialects: Shakespeare, as is well
known, spelled his name in 16 different ways, none of them "Shakespeare".
By the same token, one of our list members wrote "ridding" for "riding",
but not because he has short-i in that word.

> And the bulk of a person's communication is normally done with people
> of his own accent in which case there would be no variation.

I doubt that. In my household of four persons, there are five dialects
in use, as my daughter is nicely bi-dialectal. In any case, most of
our *written* communication is likely to be with people with different
dialects.
